comments.commentBody: The "lost Cause" used to be a romantic notion that was confined to the states below the Mason-Dixon line. Nowadays it's spread north, I wonder where all this will end? It's like reading a chapter from the Central Intelligence Agency manual on 'How to De-Stabilize a Country From Within'. All it takes is a few weak people like Boehner to allow whomever it is that is so eager to destroy the USA to succeed. How do they plan to profit from the coming chaos?

The "Lost Cause" spread to the north with the post-WWII Great Migration of southerners to the industrial belt.

In the book "American Theocracy: The Peril and Politics of Radical Religion, Oil and Borrowed Money in the 21st Century", conservative author Kevin Phillips describes the diaspora of the South to the north and western US. This spread evangelist fundamentalism and Southern style politics along with country music and rebel flags. All of this resonated with a working class caught in a downward economic spiral.

And Mr Phillips correctly presaged the Great Recession with his analogies to Dutch, British and other empires. Kevin Phillips is what Republicans used to be before The Southern Strategy. Good book, worth a read.

Manipulation of the citizenry -- and their votes -- has always been a problem for democracy, going all the way back to its cradle -- ancient Athens.

Highly skilled orators in Athens did not even bother to run for elected office because they could sway voters to their point of view by virtue of their compelling speech-making and its persuasive powers without having to get their hands dirty in the daily political grind.

Fed up with gridlock, the populace eventually welcomed strong, tyrannical leaders in Athens and then in Rome.

Are we about to do a repeat?

The mendacious re-districting by Republicans has been made possible by Republican electoral victories in state-wide contests -- democracy at a fundamental level -- so where do we set the fulcrum for democratic balance?

Majority rule has got nothing to do with wisdom and in radical democracies, as in ancient Athens, the voting bloc more than once made stupid decisions because they were duly persuaded by skilled rhetoricians and the loudest voices -- often those with ulterior motives other than the well being of all Athenians.

Sound familiar?

Gerrymandering as a tool to obtain political advantage is long overdue for constitutional overhaul. How do we make that happen?

The seeds of the ultimate destruction of the Republican Party were planted in the Civil Rights Era. The Dixiecrat switch to the Republican Party brought the Old South "Lost Cause" blockade mentality to the GOP. Gerrymandering to create safe white districts in 2010 was just the latest chapter in the long, divisive, anti-democratic GOP Southern Strategy.

The politicians like Helms and Thurmond who defended the evils of Jim Crow segregation created the template for the current Tea Party generation. They use the same basic argument to resist the extension of affordable health care insurance to over 50 million Americans that the Dixiecrats used to defend Jim Crow, the intrusion of the Federal government into state and private affairs.

FDR did not give into efforts to kill the New Deal and Social Security, including the Supreme Court. Kennedy and LBJ stood firm against the white Southern outrage of the Civil Rights era. And Obama and Democrats will not stand for blocking or eroding the carefully balanced ACA law.

Eventually, the tide of demographics will overwhelm these aging "safe" rural and suburban districts and bury the old GOP. But until then, we will have more years of the "Lost Cause". Expect more secessionist rhetoric, more blockades, shutdowns and ALEC legislation.

What a great idea! Adding two million people to the ranks of the unemployed is just what this economy needs to get it moving again--towards depression.  Layoffs beget layoffs, so perhaps you can kiss your job goodbye in the near future...

You won't find it.  Every bill they passed fully funded the govt.  The last bill rejected by the democrats fully funded the govt and asked for a one year extension to the individual mandate, similar to the one Obama gave to large businesses.

+1 for recognizing the disasterous after-effects of Reagan's collaboration with this band of circus car-clowns.

Interestingly, the former executive head of the Moral Majority was anguishing in an interview I saw the other day, over the damage they did to the moral fabic of this country.

This is completely Boehner's fault. He could have stood up to the Tea Party and let issues come up to vote without requiring a majority of the Republican party's support. He could have told the Tea Party that this is not a fight worth fighting. He could have listened to the entire House, and not just the radicalized minority. This is completely Boehner's fault.

I don't think this is Mr. Boehner's fault. The Republican Party began slipping into quicksand during the Eisenhower administration. Extreme anti-Communism started their descent into anti-government ideology. Anti-civil-rights-ism helped them sink further during the Nixon administration. Ronald Reagan's friendship with radical right-wing religious fanaticism was the final blow to any vestiges of common sense still floating around. With any luck, what we see occurring today may turn out to be the last stages of a sad, decades-long cycle of Republican political disfunction.

Please spare us and post your the drivel and lies elsewhere. You know very well that your statement about ACAs effect on your family's health insurance premium is completely false.

The Affordable Care Act is not socialism railroaded through by President Obama. You obviously skipped the "How the Bill Becomes a Law" lesson in grade-school. The ACA became a LAW through a process that is clearly outlined in the US Constitution, the supreme law of the land.

Mostly the Republican majority in the House hasn't liked ACA even when it was just a mere thought. Since it became a law, collectively, the House has voted to repeal and defund ACA 7,386 times! And they've FAILED EVERY SINGLE TIME! In 2012, the Supreme Court upheld ACA. And, more importantly, Obama was re-elected POTUS by 5 MILLION VOTES! If a majority of Americans did not want ACA, Romney would have been elected.

House Republicans have completely exhausted every one of their legal/Constitutional avenues to repeal ACA so now they are demanding that Obama, the President of the United States, govern as they would, undo/repeal a law, OR ELSE they will shut the government down and not pay the bills Congress committed to pay! Patriotic? That's an insult to the brave men and women of the armed forces who have served or are serving. They sound like crazy anarchists who are in violation of the rules of our democracy, our Constitution; and who are attempting to undo the checks and balance of power and take over!

In our state, GOP Representative Steve Pearce states that he is not getting paid.   Do I believe him? NO.  Who would believe and vote for someone who backs a group of people who seem to be dancing on the ashes of our country.
Why would an ultraconservative Representative want to deal with outsiders?  Why would they want to deal with reality, either?  Not their cup of tea.

You can get around that. Congressmen's website show a map of their district. Pick a city within their district and, on google maps, enter pizza, with city name, state. Voila, you have an address to use. Sometimes they require a zip +4. Then you have to go to USPS.com, put in the address and it will give you the 4 digit extension.
Just go online, find their district and then find an address within that district (start with an area code and go from there).  I wrote Harry Reid using Bellagio Hotel's address. . .

Interestingly these ultra conservatives are impossible to contact if you don't live in their districts. Many other representatives both Dem and Rep allow for emails from outside their district. But these extremists don't represent the American people. They represent a small constituency and they don't want to hear from anyone else.
The only answer is for the grown ups in their party to put on their big boy pants and do the right thing. This is supposed to be government for the whole. My taxes pay for their salaries and they represent me too.
I am one of the furloughed and I'm not very happy that Congress gets paid when I don't.
But years ago, we were all Americans, now we have Americans and Republicans.

Know Nothing: Because, if they did so, the Tea Party would find crazy right wing candidates to primary them in the next election and most would lose their seats. It is very simple. They care more for retaining their seats than for doing what they are supposed to do.

I suppose I am ignorant, cannot read or think clearly. But why cannot Boehner and the evidently thinking republicans in the House, merely go forward with their votes and those of agreeing Dems and get the nation on track.

Years ago the Dems had their southern nuts with presidential hopeful Wallace, and life went on

Henry Stamper: "Never give a inch!"

Sometimes I live in the country
Sometimes I live in town
Sometimes I have a great notion
to jump in the river and drown.

There may be some true-hearted principled rpresentatives in this GOP house, but they are not patriots to the demicratic & constitutional principles that are more essential to America's survival than any of their fundamentalist, reactionary postures. Standing up for your beliefs is not more important than weighing what is at stake for those you claim to protect & serve.
Perhaps they are sincere- but then it means they are not smart, not wise and ignorant of the true requirements of governing.
Who you talkin' to Mike.  Nobody who votes for the people you don't like reads this paper.
Funny how Republicans stopped being Americans; they are now Republicans.

The leaders are over at the bar with Boehner getting wacked and high-fiving
each other over their triumph. Perhaps in the sober, cold light of day they will think about the damage they have done but I doubt that they will. They will just want another drink.

Congratulations, Republicans!  You have once again appealed to your conservative base and lost the rest of the country, including most independents, who will remember your sophomoric style of "governing" during the next presidential election.  As a Republican, you have lost me.  I have left the room.  I am truly flabbergasted by your lack of vision, your myopic and blatant disregard for the country as a whole, and your inability to offer anything except obstruction.  Where have all your leaders gone?
Funny how Republicans stopped being Americans; they are now Republicans.

The leaders are over at the bar with Boehner getting wacked and high-fiving
each other over their triumph. Perhaps in the sober, cold light of day they will think about the damage they have done but I doubt that they will. They will just want another drink.

Weird that they say Obama is unwilling to negotiate when the GOP has refused for 6 months to negotiate on the budget, and they have shown no interest in negotiating now: what they offer is extortion and a list of demands. As one of them said, "I didn't come to Congress to govern!" And they're not doing it: fewer bills passed than in any Congress in history, and zero laws repealed. OTOH, close to 50 votes to defund Obamacare.

I keep reading these stories that try to convince that it is really just a small group of fanatics that want to push this perversion of the regular order to stop Obamacare. Nonsense.

Clapping and cheering all of them rushed from basement to perform this madness in unison.

But it is hard to explain. Unless of course we consider the similar experience of the men who went over the top during the trench warfare of WWI. It is not that they did indeed go over the top, but it seems most did so with zeal. Similar to the Republican zeal.

Ah, mob insanity. Yes I understand.
Yes, also please remind them that it's been deemed "Constitutional" by the Supreme Court, which is the arm of government who decides such matters.
Don't be hard on PS, Milwaukee. He or she is a reflection of the clueless Americans with no education or a view of the real picture beyond their noses. Ignorance is bliss.

Now, when Newt Gingrich proposed this plan in the 1990s, you were campaigning against it, right?

When Romney did this in Massachusetts, you fought tooth and nail to revoke it, right?

You might want to look up the definition of "socialized."
These right wing nut jobs need to be socialized.
I am glad that are some who won't give in to socialized medicine. These are the last great hero's.

@ JWC "You might want to look up the definition of "socialized.""

Alan also might want to look up the definition of "medicine", since the ACA provides insurance, not healthcare.
If this drives the majority of the House Republicans toward the center and they start ignoring this radical splinter group it may be the best thing to happen to the Republican party in decades.

While I understand why super-majority vote can be prudent in some cases, the filibuster rule of the senator guarantee that a super-majority is need to get any bill passed. The "majority of the majority rule" is the House serve no purpose except to assure the re-election of the Speaker. In fact, this House rule is a recipe for political grid lock. I would suggest that the Speaker of the House should be elected by a majority role of the FULL House instead of the ruling party.  By holding the Speaker responsible for the country instead of just his own party, these grid locks shouldn't have happened.  However, we should also note that "majority of the majority" rule is a voluntary policy choice of Mr. Boehner. Clearly the Speaker is putting his personal and ideological interests ahead of the welfare of the country.  Mr. Boehner should be ashamed for his failing to muster enough moral courage to serve the whole of the American people. Future generations will not judge the cowardice of Mr. Boehner kindly.

The article points out that these Republicans come from safe districts where, after two Republican-controlled redistrictings in 2000 & 2010, Manny the Manatee would be elected as long as he was a Tea Party Republican. The reelection danger they face is not from someone more reasonable and ready to compromise but fron someone so conservative they still believe that the earth is flat. The article also describes how confident they are, despite the polls, that now the people will see it their way. Reminds me of the President's reelection and Karl Rowe. The surprising thing is that people so out of touch with reality have so much power.
They're CONFEDERATES plain & simple.

Frankly, this seems absurd to me. One would have to compare those with high social status but low absolute wealth, with the opposite characteristics.Some members of the gilded class in the UK  may have had privileged childhoods, and acquired high permanent status through hereditary titles say,before losing their money. Their longer life may reflect health advantages persisting from childhood.

What the militant extremist are doing makes perfect sense; their concern has been that the politically moderate fighting force, which receives limited military aid from the West, has been riding in on their coattails and claiming territory, which the extremist have won on the battlefield. So, it makes perfect sense that they will claim the territory they have conquered and push all other fighting forces out of it in order to solidify their gains. Given that, the political moderates will either have to contest the territory the radical religious extremist claim, through the force of arms, or they will be tasked with carrying out assaults on Syrian Army troops in order to attempt a government take over. This is actually beneficial for the Syrian government, so long as they are willing to engage the moderates successfully, and if they can turn moderate forces against the extremist, as de facto auxiliaries. In other words, the Syrian Army may find itself fighting moderate forces on some occasions, while conversely offering military support to the moderate forces when the latter are engaged in fighting the extremist, since the two will naturally see one another as lesser evils.

Sarah - I'm sure my tax dollars are being well spent at your university.  Sorry you day was ruined worrying dealing with inquiries about all of the funding for that important research.  The first couple of weekends of each year get ruined for me compling information for an accountant to prepare my tax returns for the government funding you.  That's life.
Put it towards a Govt. Option aka Single Payer.

Why doesn't your congress axe funding for NSA and TSA instead? Put that funding toward Obama care and see how it plays out. If it is a failure, then at that time you will have complete public support to axe that one as well.

If you don't want the insurance, then pay the SMALL tax-fine instead. In fact, if you completely "opt out" of Obamacare -- I.e., you get no insurance through an exchange, you accept no subsidies, you refuse to have a ceiling on your deductibles and on lifetime coverage, and so on -- then I WILL PAY THE TAX FOR YOU. How bout it, sensible folks? Let's sponsor a "no obamacare for people who don't like it" program -- we pay their ACA tax, and they forego ALL the benefits of the law. jblees22@gmail.com
